title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. In a hypothesis test, how do you find the Z score for a point estimate?
A. $Z = \frac{\text{point estimate} - \text{null value}}{SE}$
prefix: Z score in a hypothesis test.
exact:
In the context of a hypothesis test, the Z score for a point estimate is
Z=point estimate−null valueSEZ=point estimate−null valueSEZ = \frac{\text{point estimate} - \text{null value}}{SE}
suffix: The standard error in this case

selector.exact:
In the context of a hypothesis test, the Z score for a point estimate is
Z=point estimate−null valueSEZ=point estimate−null valueSEZ = \frac{\text{point estimate} - \text{null value}}{SE}
selector.prefix: Z score in a hypothesis test.
selector.suffix: The standard error in this case

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. After flossing, we find that 15% fewer test subjects get plaque, with a 95% confidence interval of $(-5\%, 35\%)$. What can we say about flossing as an intervention?
A. Because the 95% confidence interval includes 0, this data doesn't permit us to reject the null hypothesis that flossing has no effect.
exact:
We are 95% confident that the video purchase rate resulting from the treatment is between 4.7% and 35.3% lower than in the control group.
Since this confidence interval does not contain 0, it is consistent with our earlier result where we rejected the notion of “no difference” using a hypothesis test.
suffix: Note that we have used SE = 0.0

selector.exact:
We are 95% confident that the video purchase rate resulting from the treatment is between 4.7% and 35.3% lower than in the control group.
Since this confidence interval does not contain 0, it is consistent with our earlier result where we rejected the notion of “no difference” using a hypothesis test.
selector.suffix: Note that we have used SE = 0.0

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Give the equation for the Z score of an observation $x$ drawn from $N(\mu, \sigma)$.
A. $Z=\frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}$
exact:
we define the Z score mathematically as
Z=x−μσ

selector.exact:
we define the Z score mathematically as
Z=x−μσ

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What are the parameters of a normal distribution?
A. Mean, standard deviation

Q. The mean and standard deviation are the normal distribution's…
A. Parameters
exact: they are called the distribution’s parameters

selector.exact: they are called the distribution’s parameters

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What does the Z score of an observation describe?
A. The number of standard deviations it falls above or below the mean.
exact: The Z score of an observation is defined as the number of standard deviations it falls above or below the mean
suffix:
.
If the observation is one stan

A. -1

Q. What's the Z score of a value which falls 1.2 standard deviations below the mean?
A. -1.2

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. A particular group of men averages 6' in height. Assuming height is normally distributed, how would you find the p-value of that sample statistic?
A. Calculate the Z score; find the corresponding percentile using a table or software; subtract that value from 1.
exact: We can either use statistical software or look up

selector.exact: We can either use statistical software or look up

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What's the 95% confidence interval for a point estimate of 1, assuming $SE=1$?
A. $(-0.96, 2.96)$

Q. How to find the 95% confidence interval for a point estimate of a normally distributed sample statistic?
A. $\text{point estimate} \pm 1.96 \times SE$

Q. If the 95% confidence interval of some point estimate is $(-1, 1)$, what does that tell us?
A. 95% of the time, the true population parameter is within that interval.
exact:
Thus, a 95% confidence interval for such a point estimate can be constructed:
point estimate±1.96×SEpoint estimate±1.96×SE\text{point estimate} \pm 1.96 \times SE
suffix: We can be 95% confident this int

selector.exact:
Thus, a 95% confidence interval for such a point estimate can be constructed:
point estimate±1.96×SEpoint estimate±1.96×SE\text{point estimate} \pm 1.96 \times SE
selector.suffix: We can be 95% confident this int

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Which quantity do confidence intervals describe the confidence of capturing—individual observations, population parameters, proportions of observations, point estimates? 
A. population parameters
exact:
Our intervals say nothing about the confidence of capturing individual observations, a proportion of the observations, or about capturing point estimates.
Confidence intervals provide an interval estimate for and attempt to capture population parameters.

selector.exact:
Our intervals say nothing about the confidence of capturing individual observations, a proportion of the observations, or about capturing point estimates.
Confidence intervals provide an interval estimate for and attempt to capture population parameters.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Confidence intervals are imperfect. What sorts of failures should you expect?
A. e.g. Over a lifetime of creating 95% confidence intervals, 5% of those intervals will miss the true value.
exact: Indeed, over a lifetime of creating 95% intervals, you should expect 5% of your reported intervals to miss the parameter of interest

selector.exact: Indeed, over a lifetime of creating 95% intervals, you should expect 5% of your reported intervals to miss the parameter of interest

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Slightly more precise version of the heuristic that 95% of samples from a normal distribution fall within 2 standard deviations of the mean?
A. 95% fall within 1.96 standard deviations.
exact: Here, we use the value 1.96 to be slightly more precise.

selector.exact: Here, we use the value 1.96 to be slightly more precise.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. The margin of error of a sampling distribution is 2. What does that tell you?
A. 95% of sample statistic point estimates will fall within $\mu \pm 2$
exact: That is, 95% of the observations are within one margin of error of the mean.
suffix: Margin of error for sample pro

selector.exact: That is, 95% of the observations are within one margin of error of the mean.
selector.suffix: Margin of error for sample pro

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What does the margin of error describe?
A. How far point estimates of the sample statistic will fall from the sampling distribution's mean.
prefix: d error is the margin of error.
exact: The margin of error describes how far away observations are from their mean.

selector.exact: The margin of error describes how far away observations are from their mean.
selector.prefix: d error is the margin of error.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. How is the standard error defined?
A. It's the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.

Q. How does the standard error differ from the standard deviation of the observations?
A. The standard error describes the variability of point estimates of some sample statistic, rather than the variability of observed data.
exact: The standard error is equal to the standard deviation associated with the statistic
suffix:
.
So, for example, to quantify t

selector.exact: The standard error is equal to the standard deviation associated with the statistic
selector.suffix:
.
So, for example, to quantify t

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What's the 95%-confidence margin of error for a sampling distribution $N(\mu=3, \sigma=2)$?
A. 4 (i.e. $2 \times SE = 2 \times \sigma$)
exact: we say that the margin of error is approximately 2×SE2×SE2 \times SE

selector.exact: we say that the margin of error is approximately 2×SE2×SE2 \times SE

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Rule of thumb for approximating the standard deviation from samples of a random normal variable?
A. Divide the distance between the highest and lowest sample by 4.
exact: Notice that if the spread of the observations goes from some lower bound to some upper bound, a rough approximation of the SE is to divide the range by 4.
suffix: That is, if you notice the samp

selector.exact: Notice that if the spread of the observations goes from some lower bound to some upper bound, a rough approximation of the SE is to divide the range by 4.
selector.suffix: That is, if you notice the samp

Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics

Q. What term describes the variability of point estimates from sample to sample?
A. The standard error (SE)

exact: and we quantify this variability with what is called the standard error (SE)

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. The 68-95-99.7 rule describes…?
A. The probability that a sample falls within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of a normal distribution's mean.

Q. What rule of thumb describes the probability of falling within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of a normal distribution's mean?
A. The 68-95-99.7 rule.

Q. What fraction of values fall between $x=0$ and $x=1$ in $N(\mu=0, \sigma=1)$?
A. 0.34 (0.68 per the 68-95-99.7 rule, divided by 2)

Q. What's the probability of sampling $x=-2$ and $x=2$ from $N(\mu=0, \sigma=2)$?
A. 0.68

Q. What's the area under $N(\mu=1, \sigma=2)$ between -1 and 1?
A. 0.475 (0.95 per the 68-95-99.7 rule, divided by 2)

Q. What percentage of samples fall between $x=-6$ and $x=6$ in $N(\mu=0, \sigma=2)$?
A. 99.7%
prefix: hout a calculator or Z table.
exact: Figure 13.8: Probabilities for falling within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution.
suffix: Use pnorm() (or a Z table) t

selector.exact: Figure 13.8: Probabilities for falling within 1, 2, and 3 standard deviations of the mean in a normal distribution.
selector.prefix: hout a calculator or Z table.
selector.suffix: Use pnorm() (or a Z table) t

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What's the geometric interpretation of a normally distributed observation's percentile?
A. The area under the normal curve to the left of that value.

Q. What's the probabilistic interpretation of a normally distributed observation's percentile?
A. The probability that a sample drawn from the distribution will be at or below that value.

Q. What's the total area under the normal curve?
A. 1
exact:
Nel’s percentile is the percentage of people who earned a lower SAT score than Nel.
We shade the area representing those individuals in Figure 13.6.
The total area under the normal curve is always equal to 1, and the proportion of people who scored below Nel on the SAT is equal to the area shaded in Figure 13.6: 0.8413.
In other words, Nel is in the 84th84th84^{th} percentile of SAT takers.

selector.exact:
Nel’s percentile is the percentage of people who earned a lower SAT score than Nel.
We shade the area representing those individuals in Figure 13.6.
The total area under the normal curve is always equal to 1, and the proportion of people who scored below Nel on the SAT is equal to the area shaded in Figure 13.6: 0.8413.
In other words, Nel is in the 84th84th84^{th} percentile of SAT takers.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. How would you determine the probability that a random person's height is between 5' and 6'?
A. Calculate the Z values for 5' and 6'; find the corresponding percentiles using a table or computer; subtract the 5' percentile from the 6' percentile.
exact: What is the probability that a randomly selected adult male is between 5’9’’ and 6’2’’?

selector.exact: What is the probability that a randomly selected adult male is between 5’9’’ and 6’2’’?

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. How would you determine the probability that a random student scores above an SAT score $x$?
A. Calculate the Z score for $x$; find the corresponding percentile using a table or computer; subtract that value from 1.
exact:
Shannon is a randomly selected SAT taker, and nothing is known about Shannon’s SAT aptitude.
What is the probability that Shannon scores at least 1630 on their SATs?
suffix: First, always draw and label a

selector.exact:
Shannon is a randomly selected SAT taker, and nothing is known about Shannon’s SAT aptitude.
What is the probability that Shannon scores at least 1630 on their SATs?
selector.suffix: First, always draw and label a

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Assuming height is normally distributed, how would you find what height corresponds to the 20th percentile?
A. Find the corresponding Z score (using a table or software); solve $Z = \frac{x-\mu}{\sigma}$ for $x$.
exact:
The last several problems have focused on finding the probability or percentile for a particular observation.
What if you would like to know the observation corresponding to a particular percentile?

selector.exact:
The last several problems have focused on finding the probability or percentile for a particular observation.
What if you would like to know the observation corresponding to a particular percentile?

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. An observation's Z score is 0.43, which is 67th percentile. What's the probability of seeing a higher sample?
A. 0.33
exact: Determine the proportion of SAT test takers who scored better than Nel on the SAT.142

selector.exact: Determine the proportion of SAT test takers who scored better than Nel on the SAT.142

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. How can you compare how unusual two observations are by their Z scores?
A. The Z score with the larger absolute value is more unusual.
prefix: s are more unusual than others.
exact: One observation x1x1x_1 is said to be more unusual than another observation x2x2x_2 if the absolute value of its Z score is larger than the absolute value of the other observation’s Z score: |Z1|>|Z2|

selector.exact: One observation x1x1x_1 is said to be more unusual than another observation x2x2x_2 if the absolute value of its Z score is larger than the absolute value of the other observation’s Z score: |Z1|>|Z2|
selector.prefix: s are more unusual than others.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. If I draw samples from a normal distribution, how are those observations' Z scores distributed?
A. According to a standard normal distribution (irrespective of the original distribution's parameters).
exact: the Z score will be distributed according to a normal distribution with a center of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

selector.exact: the Z score will be distributed according to a normal distribution with a center of 0 and a standard deviation of 1.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Notation for a normal distribution with a mean of 5 and a standard deviation of 2?
A. $N(\mu = 5, \sigma = 2)$
exact: we may write the distribution as N(μ,σ).N(μ,σ).N(\mu, \sigma).

selector.exact: we may write the distribution as N(μ,σ).N(μ,σ).N(\mu, \sigma).

Q. What's the standard normal distribution?
A. A normal distribution with mean $0$ and standard deviation $1$.

Q. The ubiquitous bell-shaped curve describes what distribution?
A. The normal distribution.
exact: normal distribution

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Roughly how many observations do you need for the central limit theorem to apply to a sample proportion?
A. At least 10 successes and 10 failures.
exact: For proportions, at least 10 expected successes and 10 expected failures in the sample

selector.exact: For proportions, at least 10 expected successes and 10 expected failures in the sample

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What two conditions must be met for the central limit theorem to hold for sample proportions?
A. Observations must be independent; there can't be too few of them.
exact:
Observations in the sample are independent.
Independence is guaranteed when we take a random sample from a population.
Independence can also be guaranteed if we randomly divide individuals into treatment and control groups.
The sample is large enough.
The sample size cannot be too small.
What qualifies as “small” differs from one context to the next, and we’ll provide suitable guidelines for proportions in Chapter 16.
suffix: So far we have had no need for

selector.exact:
Observations in the sample are independent.
Independence is guaranteed when we take a random sample from a population.
Independence can also be guaranteed if we randomly divide individuals into treatment and control groups.
The sample is large enough.
The sample size cannot be too small.
What qualifies as “small” differs from one context to the next, and we’ll provide suitable guidelines for proportions in Chapter 16.
selector.suffix: So far we have had no need for

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What claim does the Central Limit Theorem make of sample proportions?
A. Sample proportions, and differences of sample proportions, will approximate a normal distribution (subject to certain conditions).
exact: the sample proportion (or difference in proportions) will appear to follow a bell-shaped curve called the normal distribution
suffix:
.

An example of a perfect norma

selector.exact: the sample proportion (or difference in proportions) will appear to follow a bell-shaped curve called the normal distribution

.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. I flip a coin many times to see if it's fair. What value is the null distribution centered around?
A. 0.5
exact: the null distribution will always be centered at the value of the parameter given by the null hypothesis
suffix:
.
In the case of the opportunity

selector.exact: the null distribution will always be centered at the value of the parameter given by the null hypothesis
selector.suffix:
.
In the case of the opportunity

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What values does the null distribution describe?
A. The sample statistics you'd observe if the null hypothesis were true.
exact: the null distribution is the sampling distribution of the statistic created under the setting where the null hypothesis is true

selector.exact: the null distribution is the sampling distribution of the statistic created under the setting where the null hypothesis is true

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Since we usually have only one sample statistic, how can we ever work with sampling distributions?
A. We can estimate them from their expected mathematical structure.
exact: we use either computational or mathematical structures to estimate the sampling distribution
suffix: and hence to describe the expec

selector.exact: we use either computational or mathematical structures to estimate the sampling distribution
selector.suffix: and hence to describe the expec

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. Why is it difficult to visualize a sampling distribution directly from a single dataset?
A. A single dataset yields only one sample statistic. Plotting one point won't show you a distribution.
exact: However, because a sampling distribution describes sample statistics computed from many studies, it cannot be visualized directly from a single dataset.

selector.exact: However, because a sampling distribution describes sample statistics computed from many studies, it cannot be visualized directly from a single dataset.

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. To decide if a coin is fair, I flip it ten times. What does this experiment's sampling distribution describe?
A. The sample proportion: how many times the coin came up "heads" in those ten flips.
exact: e.g. the sample proportion ^pp^\hat{p} or the sample mean ¯x

selector.exact: e.g. the sample proportion ^pp^\hat{p} or the sample mean ¯x

title: Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What values does a sampling distribution describe?
A. Sample statistics (of some population, at some sample size)
exact: A sampling distribution is the distribution of all possible values of a sample statistic from samples of a given sample size from a given population
suffix:
.
We can think about the sample

selector.exact: A sampling distribution is the distribution of all possible values of a sample statistic from samples of a given sample size from a given population

.

Chapter 13 Inference with mathematical models | Introduction to Modern Statistics
text:
Q. What's the difference between a data distribution and a sampling distribution?
A. The data distribution describes observed values (e.g. individuals' heights); the sampling distribution describes sample statistics (e.g. average height of a population sample);
prefix: ries from one study to another.
exact: A sampling distribution is contrasted with a data distribution which shows the variability of the observed data values
